sources.title: New Faces (1954) EARTHA KITT MUSICAL
sources.description:
Exclusive Movie Class by PizzaFLIX Edition! 
Starring: Eartha Kitt, Paul Lynde, Robert Clary, Alice Ghostley
CHAPTERS
0:00      Movie Class Introduction
1:54      Feature film begins
44:53    Santa Baby by Eartha Kitt
1:39:08 Please Subscribe

Beginning in 1934, Leonard Sillman produced a series of live musical revues that introduced up and coming stars. The ‘52 revue opened at Broadway’s Royale Theatre with Robert Clary, Alice Ghostley, Paul Lynde, and of course Eartha Kitt. Comedy by sketches by Mel Brooks, and musical direction courtesy of Anton Coppola, uncle of Frances. It ran for 365 performances through March of 1953.

Retitled simply "New Faces," a version of the ’52 Broadway revue was filmed in Hollywood on Cinemascope for Twentieth Century Fox. Most of the original cast returned, with the song order expanded to include Kitt's slinky Christmas hit.  A typical movie musical plot was tossed in, but make no mistake you are watching this for EARTHA KITT in her big-screen debut… prepare to be WOWED!

sources.title: New Faces (1954) Comedy, Musical, Color Movie
sources.description:
The plot involved a producer and performer (Ronny Graham) in financial trouble and is trying to stave off an angry creditor long enough to open his show. A wealthy Texan offers to help out, on the condition that his daughter be in the show. New Faces was a musical revue with songs and comedy skits tied together by a quirky plot. It ran on Broadway for nearly a year in 1952 and was then made into a motion picture in 1954. It helped jump start the careers of several young performers including Paul Lynde, Alice Ghostley, Eartha Kitt, Carol Lawrence, performer/writer Mel Brooks (as Melvin Brooks), and lyricist Sheldon Harnick.

Directors: Harry Horner, John Beal
Writers: Ronny Graham, Mel Brooks
Stars: Ronny Graham, Eartha Kitt, Robert Clary 
Genres: Classics, Comedy, Musical

sources.title: New Faces (aka 'New Faces of 1952') (Widescreen 1954)
sources.description: A filmed performance (in CinemaScope) of the highly popular Broadway hit that was basically a collection of skits, sketches, songs and dances built around a flimsy plot to meld them all together which, for the most part, worked. The plot involves a performer/producer (Ronny Graham)who finds himself in financial difficulties on the eve of opening night because a big check is needed before the curtain can go up. But a wealthy Texan says he will put up the money, if his daughter is in the show and he can see it first. End of plot, but the beginning of the careers of some young and talented people who have had careers across many decades. Ertha Kitt sings four songs, including "C'est Si Bon" and "Santa Baby" in and around some funny skits; "Trip of the Month", "Snake Charmer", "Crazy Man" and "Oedipus Goes South." Graham and Mel Brooks (in his Melvin Brooks days)are credited with most of the sketch material and just the title of the "Oedipus" bit suggests Brooks. There is a burlesque of "Death of a Salesman", which was probably the easiest to write of all. It also appears that when Brooks later did "The Producers", he hadn't forgotten everything about "New Faces." Written by Les Adams

metadata.Plot: A filmed performance (in CinemaScope) of the highly popular Broadway hit that was basically a collection of skits, sketches, songs and dances built around a flimsy plot to meld them all together which, for the most part, worked. The plot involves a performer/producer (Ronny Graham) who finds himself in financial difficulties on the eve of opening night because a big check is needed before the curtain can go up. But a wealthy Texan says he will put up the money, if his daughter is in the show and he can see it first. End of plot, but the beginning of the careers of some young and talented people who have had careers across many decades. Eartha Kitt sings four songs, including "C'est si bon" (music by Henri Betti, lyrics by André Hornez) and "Santa Baby" in and around some funny skits; "Trip of the Month", "Snake Charmer", "Crazy Man" and "Oedipus Goes South." Graham and Mel Brooks (in his Melvin Brooks days) are credited with most of the sketch material and just the title of the "Oedipus" bit suggests Brooks. There is a burlesque of "Death of a Salesman", which was probably the easiest to write of all. It also appears that when Brooks later did "The Producers", he hadn't forgotten everything about "New Faces".
metadata.Writer: Ronny Graham, Mel Brooks, Paul Lynde
